bibl.title: Letter from Lucius W. Johnson to Philip Showalter Hench, February 26, 1949

div1.p: Johnson requests permission to use a reproduction of Cornwell's painting “Conquerors of Yellow Fever” for an article he is writing on yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Lucius W. Johnson to Philip Showalter Hench, February 26, 1949
div1.opener:
LUCIUS W. JOHNSON, M. D.
3414 FREEMAN STREET
SAN DIEGO 6, CALIFORNIA
26 February, 1949.
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
In my files on yellow fever is a let-
ter from you, dated 29 January, 1942, which expresses
interest in an article concerning yellow fever. The
article has been completed at last, and has been ac-
cepted for publication in Proceedings of the U.S.
Naval Institute, Annapolis, Md. The article is fo-
cussed on the profound influence that the disease
has had on the strategy of all our wars.

Would it be possible to obtain per-
mission to use the illustration ‘Conquerers of Yel-
low Fever’, either in color as it was in your article
in Hygeia for October, 1941, or in black and white
as it appeared in Proceedings of the Staff Meetings,
Mayo Clinic, in the following December?

I should be most grateful if you
can tell me who has the copyright, and whether or
not the color plates could be borrowed.
